Integrated Diversity, Dominance, and Evenness Indices

Source: R/alpha_integrated.r
alpha_integrated.Rd

This category includes the most widely used diversity indices. Unlike richness metrics, these indices integrate both the number of species (richness) and their relative abundances (evenness) into a single value. They differ primarily in their sensitivity to rare versus abundant species, a property elegantly captured by the Hill number framework.

Usage

berger(counts, cpus = n_cpus())

brillouin(counts, cpus = n_cpus())

fisher(counts, digits = 3L, cpus = n_cpus())

inv_simpson(counts, cpus = n_cpus())

mcintosh(counts, cpus = n_cpus())

shannon(counts, cpus = n_cpus())

simpson(counts, cpus = n_cpus())

Arguments

counts

A numeric matrix of count data where each column is a sample, and each row is a feature. Any object coercible with as.matrix() can be given here, as well as phyloseq, rbiom, SummarizedExperiment, and TreeSummarizedExperiment objects.

cpus

How many parallel processing threads should be used. The default, n_cpus(), will use all logical CPU cores.

digits

Precision of the returned values, in number of decimal places. E.g. the default digits=3 could return 6.392.

Value

A numeric vector.

Calculation

Given:

\(x_i\):

Integer count of the \(i\)-th feature (species).

\(p_i\):

Proportional abundance of the \(i\)-th feature (species).

\(S\):

Number of features (e.g. species).

\(N\):

Number of observations (e.g. sequencing depth).

Berger-Parker Index berger()

$$D = \displaystyle \max(p)$$

Brillouin Index brillouin()

$$D = \displaystyle \frac{\ln{[(\sum_{i = 1}^{S} x_i)!]} - \sum_{i = 1}^{S} \ln{(x_i!)}}{\sum_{i = 1}^{S} x_i}$$

Fisher's Alpha (\(\alpha\)) fisher()

$$S = \alpha \times \ln(1 + \frac{N}{\alpha})$$

The value of \(\alpha\) must be solved for iteratively.

Inverse Simpson Index inv_simpson()

$$D = \displaystyle 1 / \sum_{i = 1}^{S} p_i \times \ln(p_i)$$

McIntosh Index mcintosh()

$$D = \displaystyle \frac{N - \sqrt{\sum_{i = 1}^{S} (x_i)^2}}{N - \sqrt{N}}$$

Shannon Diversity Index shannon()

$$D = \displaystyle -\sum_{i = 1}^{S} p_i \times \ln(p_i)$$

Gini-Simpson Index simpson()

$$D = \displaystyle 1 - \sum_{i = 1}^{S} p_i \times \ln(p_i)$$

  x <- c(1, 1, 3, 2, 6)
  p <- x / sum(x)

  # Berger-Parker
  max(p)
  #> [1] 0.4615385

  # Brillouin Index
  # note: lgamma(x + 1) == log(x!)
  (lgamma(sum(x) + 1) - sum(lgamma(x + 1))) / sum(x)
  #> [1] 1.037539

  # Inverse Simpson Index
  1 / sum(p * log(p))
  #> [1] -0.7257845

  # McIntosh Index
  (sum(x) - sqrt(sum(x^2))) / (sum(x) - sqrt(sum(x)))
  #> [1] -0.7257845

  # Shannon Diversity Index
  -sum(p * log(p))
  #> [1] 1.37782

  # Gini-Simpson Index
  1 - sum(p * log(p))
  #> [1] 2.309526

References

Berger, W. H., & Parker, F. L. (1970). Diversity of planktonic foraminifera in deep-sea sediments. Science, 168(3937), 1345–1347. doi:10.1126/science.168.3937.1345

Brillouin, L. (1956). Science and information theory. Academic Press.

Fisher, R.A., Corbet, A.S., & Williams, C.B. (1943). The relation between the number of species and the number of individuals in a random sample of animal population. Journal of Animal Ecology, 12, 42-58.

McIntosh, R.P. (1967). An Index of Diversity and the Relation of Certain Concepts to Diversity. Ecology, 48(3), 392–404. doi:10.2307/1932674

Shannon CE, Weaver W 1949. The Mathematical Theory of Communication. University of Illinois Press.

Simpson EH 1949. Measurement of diversity. Nature, 163. doi:10.1038/163688a0

Examples

    # Example counts matrix
    ex_counts
#>                   Saliva Gums Nose Stool
#> Streptococcus        162  793   22     1
#> Bacteroides            2    4    2   611
#> Corynebacterium        0    0  498     1
#> Haemophilus          180   87    2     1
#> Propionibacterium      1    1  251     0
#> Staphylococcus         0    1  236     1
    
    berger(ex_counts)
#>    Saliva      Gums      Nose     Stool 
#> 0.5217391 0.8950339 0.4925816 0.9934959 
    
    brillouin(ex_counts)
#> Error in assert_integer_counts(): object 'counts' not found
    
    fisher(ex_counts)
#> Error in assert_integer_counts(): object 'counts' not found
    
    inv_simpson(ex_counts)
#> Error in validate_rescale(<environment>): could not find function "validate_rescale"
    
    mcintosh(ex_counts)
#> Error in validate_rescale(<environment>): could not find function "validate_rescale"
    
    shannon(ex_counts)
#> Error in validate_rescale(<environment>): could not find function "validate_rescale"
    
    simpson(ex_counts)
#> Error in validate_rescale(<environment>): could not find function "validate_rescale"
